detaileddescription.para: The util::Result class provides a standard way for functions to return either error messages or result values.

It is intended for high-level functions that need to report error strings to end users. Lower-level functions that don't need this error-reporting and that only need error-handling should avoid util::Result and instead use util::Expected, std::optional, std::variant, or custom structs and enum types to return function results.

Usage examples can be found in, but in general code returning util::Result<T> values is very similar to code returning std::optional<T> values. Existing functions returning std::optional<T> can be updated to return util::Result<T> and return error strings usually just replacing return std::nullopt; with return util::Error{error_string};.
